results.title: Dame Edith Sitwell
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Face to Face”.
John Freeman interviews Dame Edith Sitwell with the aim of observing the person behind the public face. A distinguished poet who lists her recreations as “listening to music and silence”. She received honorary doctorates from the Universities of Leeds, Durham, Oxford and Sheffield and was an Honorary Associate of the American Institute of Arts and Letters. Her first poems were published in 1915. This interview was recorded in 1959. Dame Edith Sitwell died on 9th December, 1964, at the age of 77, a few days after finishing her memoirs “Taken care of”. Drawings by Feliks Topolski.

results.title: Damascus
results.brief_description: Part of the Vagabond Adventure series, shows scenes of Damascus including buildings, ruins, bazaars, streetscapes, artisans at work on intricate mother-of-pearl inlays, brass ornaments and the market places. Narrated by Alois Hovrilla.
results.description: Part of the Vagabond Adventure series, shows scenes of Damascus including buildings, ruins, bazaars, streetscapes, artisans at work on intricate mother-of-pearl inlays, brass ornaments and the market places. Narrated by Alois Hovrilla.

results.title: Damage (E)
results.creator_credit: Louis Malle, Channel 4, Studio Canal+ and Skerba NEF
results.brief_description: Jeremy Irons and Juliette Binoche star in this Louis Malle erotic film about dangerous sexual obsession. Irons, a respected MP, becomes attracted and then involved with his son’s fiance Anna. Despite his promising career, his successful marriage to Miranda Richardson and the love he bears for his son, he cannot bear to give Anna up, and they pursue a dangerous affair which ultimately ends in tragedy. Martin, played by Rupert Graves becomes the innocent victim of their deceit. Miranda Richardson gives a strong albeit brief performance, while Leslie Caron makes a cameo appearance as Anna’s mother.

results.title: Dama a sobachkoi = Lady with the little dog
results.brief_description:
In Yalta, at the end of the 19th century, an unhappily married woman goes on a holiday alone, walking her dog daily to relive her ennui. A banker named Dimitri, beguiled by Anna’s beauty, admires her from afar, himself suffering in a miserable arranged marriage. The two embark upon a hopeless affair, which Anna assumes will end with the holiday. Dimitri returns to Moscow but distracted by the memory of Anna, contrives to see her again. Back in Saratov, Anna is equally as depressed and most surprised when Dimitri arrives at a concert she is attending. Drawn together by their misery, the lovers continue to meet intermittently in the hope of salvaging a schism of love from their ruined lives. Displaying a fondness for the manners and social mores of turn of the century Russia, Heifits contrasts the brightness of Yalta in summer (symbolic of the passionate beginnings of the affair), with the cold Moscow winter. The low-key direction and emotional undercurrents of the film adequately reflect the power of Chekhov’s prose.

Credits: Director, writer, Josef Heifits ; photography, Andrei Moskvin, D. Meschiev ; music, Jiri Sternwald.
Cast: Iya Savvina, Aleksei Batalov, Nina Alisova, Pantelejmon Krymov, D. Zebrovv, M. Safonova.

results.title: Dalziel and Scullion [Widescreen]
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “TheEYE”.
Part of a series of interview-based profiles of contemporary visual artists in Britain. Artists Matthew Dalziel and Louise Scullion have worked together since 1993, based in the remote north east of Scotland. Using photography, video, sculpture, sound and installation, they have created a collection of work that is recognised for its distinctive vision and sensitivity to its context and the environment. The point at which nature and culture intersect is a continuing theme throughout their work. Well known for their site-specific works, which include important public commissions, their art reflects on the primary themes of landscape, evolution, religion and time, and represents a rediscovery of landscape as a means of reflecting on fundamental ideas about the world we live in today. In this profile, Dalziel and Scullion discuss their continuing fascination with timescales and how their work attempts to reflect on the vast gap that exists between the limits of human history and the incomprehensible span of geological processes and creation.

results.title: Dalton Trumbo
results.creator_credit: Barbara Gordon and National Educational Television
results.brief_description: Dalton Trumbo, once a blacklisted author and screenwriter, summoned to appear before the House Committee for Un-American Activities in 1947, recalls his subsequent conviction for contempt of Congress. Trumbo explains his controversial decision to turn his anti-war novel, ‘Johnny got his gun’ into a feature film.
results.description: Dalton Trumbo, once a blacklisted author and screenwriter, summoned to appear before the House Committee for Un-American Activities in 1947, recalls his subsequent conviction for contempt of Congress. results.title: Dalmas
results.brief_description: Dalmas was a key work in independent cinema of its time, and it’s still a fascinating cinema experience. Made on a collective basis mainly with members of the communal artistic performing group, The Tribe. Heavily influenced by hallucinations and the philosophy of the time, the film also impresses with its formal innovation.

results.title: Daleks: invasion Earth 2150 A.D. [Widescreen]
results.brief_description: Based on a story from the BBC TV serial “Doctor Who”, Dr. Who and his companions arrive on Earth in the year 2150 AD, only to discover that the planet has been invaded and its population enslaved by the dreaded Daleks. The time travellers assist human resistance groups to foil the Daleks’ plan to mine the Earth’s core.

images.caption: Daleks: invasion Earth 2150 A.D.  (Gordon Flemyng) still

results.title: Dalekmania
results.creator_credit: Kevin Davies, John Farbrother and Amity Productions
results.brief_description: It’s 1965 in England: the BBC TV serial ‘Doctor Who’ is presently on every home TV. A 6 part Dalek adventure has just finished - Dalekmania is at it’s height. Milton Subotsky and Max J. Rosenberg competing against ‘Hammer Horror’, decide to cash in on the Dalekmania - they release their first Dalek movie : “Dr. Who and the Daleks”. No one had ever seen Daleks in colour, so in the wide-screen film, Daleks of all colours dominated the screen. Peter Cushing played the Doctor, unlike the TV serial. Although the film was separate from the BBC production - it was highly successful. So successful they made another movie : “Dalek - Invasion Earth 2150 A.D.”, a year later whilst Daleks were still on people’s minds. In this short film we see snippets and trailers from these two movies; hear interesting stories from the actors involved; and those wonderful toys and memorabilia that have become extremely collectable.

results.title: Dalai Lama in Australia production
results.brief_description:
An audio visual recording of the following events as part of the visit to Australia in May 2002 by His Holiness the 14th Dalai Lama of Tibet:

4.00 pm Sunday 19th May 2002: Public Talk by Dalai Lama

8.30 am Monday 20th May 2002: Teaching by Dalai Lama: Atisha’s,
A Lamp to the Path to Enlightenment.

11.15 am Monday 20th May 2002: Victorian Secondary Schools
Event with the Dalai Lama and Sigrid Thornton as MC.
5 Students will ask questions of the Dalai Lama.

2.00 pm Monday 20th May 2002: Teaching by the Dalai Lama:
Atisha’s Lamp to the Path to Enlightenment

9.30 am Tuesday 21st May 2002: Teaching by the Dalai Lama:
Atisha’s Lamp to the Path to Enlightenment

2.00 pm Tuesday 21st May 2002: Teaching by the Dalai Lama:
Atisha’s Lamp to the Path to Enlightenment

9.30 am Wednesday 22nd May 2002: Semkye and Chenrezig Jenang
Empowerment by the Dalai Lama

2.00 pm Wednesday 22nd May 2002: Teaching by the Dalai Lama:
Atisha’s Lamp to the Path to Enlightement
